Further research would be needed to provide a conclusive answer.

Claim: Does brisk walking lower mortality? Is some exercise better than none at all?
Justification: Brisk walking has been associated with a lower mortality risk compared to slow walking, even when considering an otherwise unhealthy lifestyle. This is evident in the estimated 10-year survival rates, which were higher in brisk walkers who engaged in an unhealthy lifestyle compared to slow walkers who engaged in a healthy lifestyle: 97.1% vs 95.0% in women and 94.8% vs 93.7% in men. Brisk walking has been identified as a moderate-intensity exercise, suitable for meeting American College of Sport Medicine/Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommendations. It has been suggested that brisk walking is of sufficient intensity to elicit a training response in all but the most highly fit patients with coronary disease. Furthermore, brisk walking is recommended for obese individuals as it may reduce the risk of musculoskeletal injury while providing proper cardiovascular stimulus. Even a modest increase in physical activity, such as brisk walking, can have a significant impact on health and quality of life. Therefore, it can be concluded that brisk walking does lower mortality and that some exercise is better than none at all.

Claim: Can arthroscopy reduce pain or improve mobility?
Justification: Arthroscopy, a minimally invasive surgical procedure, has been shown to reduce pain and improve mobility in patients with various joint pathologies. This is achieved through the removal of loose bodies, debridement of damaged tissue, and repair or reconstruction of ligaments and cartilage. In cases of anterior impingement syndrome, arthroscopic treatment has been found to increase range of motion. Similarly, for inflammatory arthropathies, arthroscopy with debridement and synovectomy can relieve pain, improve function, and delay disease progression. However, the effectiveness of arthroscopic debridement with or without meniscectomy for relieving pain and improving functional outcomes is uncertain. It is also important to note that arthroscopy is not a cure for osteoarthritis, but it can provide significant benefits to patients with intra-articular pathology. The role of arthroscopy in the treatment of glenohumeral arthritis is evolving, and it is a viable option in certain situations and patients. Nonetheless, in cases where there is no mechanical damage to the knee, nonsurgical conservative methods are recommended. Therefore, while arthroscopy can reduce pain and improve mobility, it should be considered as part of a comprehensive treatment plan tailored to the individual patient's needs and circumstances.

Claim: Do health benefits increase with duration and intensity of exercise?
Justification: Justification: The beneficial effect on cardiovascular health and metabolism is augmented by a higher duration and intensity of exercise. Many exercise-related health benefits exhibit a dose-response relationship, indicating that up to a certain point, more exercise is more beneficial. Increasing exercise duration and intensity beyond current recommendations appears to impart additional cardiovascular benefits for most of the population. However, recent data suggests the possibility of an inflection point after which additional exercise may no longer impart benefits and may even result in negative cardiovascular outcomes. Regular exercise results in increases in life expectancy and protects against adverse cardiac events in both healthy subjects and patients with cardiovascular disease. Different exercise intensities may provide distinct health benefits, independent of energy expenditure. The capacity for human exercise performance can be enhanced with prolonged exercise training, whether it is endurance- or strength-based. Chronic exercise or high levels of physical activity have been shown to improve vaccination responses in older adults, illustrating improved immune function. Cohort studies suggest that 'more is better' regarding the exercise dose for increasing cardiorespiratory fitness and that this is mediated through increased cardiorespiratory fitness. A growing body of evidence suggests that exercise training with low-volume but high-intensity may be a time-efficient means to achieve health benefits. Robust epidemiological evidence exists that lifelong regular exercise contributes to longevity. Exercise training above the public health recommendations provides additional benefits regarding disease protection and longevity.
